{F2_GRANDMOTHER} includes one-on-one time with her granddaughter as part of her bedtime routine, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. Let‚Äôs see how they do it together!

{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: I am so happy to see you playing quietly with your blocks, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. When I come back, it will be time to get ready for bed. When you are ready for bed, we can have 5 minutes of One-on-One Time together.
{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Okay!
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: Time to get ready for bed. First, let‚Äôs get you a nice body wash.
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: You were so well-behaved in the bath, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}. Now it is time to put on your Pajamas .
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: Well done for getting in your pajamas all by yourself, {F2_DAUGHTER_3}! Now you brush your teeth. Make sure you get the ones in the back of your mouth!
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: You were so cooperative while getting ready for bed! Now we have 5 minutes of one-on-one time to spend together. What would you like to do?
{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Yay! Can you read me my favourite storybook?
{F2_GRANDMOTHER}: ‚ÄúThe end‚Ä¶.‚Äù Such a lovely story! Goodnight my darling girl. I love you very much.
{F2_DAUGHTER_3}: Goodnight, Grandma

üòÉüò£üòîThis lesson is about noticing your and @fields.child_nickname‚Äôs feelings during One-on-One Time.

SourceText: üòÉüò£üòîThis lesson is about noticing your and your child‚Äôs feelings during One-on-One Time.
üå∑ You can help by listening to them, thinking about how it must feel for them, and accepting their emotions.
ü§óThis will help them recognise other people‚Äôs feelings, too.
Let‚Äôs do a True/False quiz:
Talking about pleasant feelings is not as important as sharing unpleasant feelings.
6Ô∏è‚É£There are six basic emotions: Happy, Sad, Angry, Disgusted, Surprised, and Afraid.
‚úÖIt‚Äôs important that we talk with our children about ALL of them.
üéâThat‚Äôs correct.
Here‚Äôs another one: Boys should not share when they are feeling sad or afraid.
‚≠ê It is important that both children learn how to share their feelings.
üíô Children will learn that it is okay to feel sad or afraid and ask for help when they need it.
üíô Children will learn that it is okay to feel sad or afraid and to ask for help when they need it.
Last one: As parents, we can also share our feelings with our children.
üéâ Correct!
üå± Sharing our own feelings with our children in a calm way shows them how to do it themselves.
üëÄOops! Good Try!
Let‚Äôs see how {F3_MOTHER} helps her girl persist with a difficult activity during one-on-one time
{F3_MOTHER}: {F3_DAUGHTER_7}, I have 5 minutes to spend One-on-One Time with you. What would you like to do?
{F3_DAUGHTER_7}: Let‚Äôs play with the ball outside!
{F3_DAUGHTER_7}: I‚Äôm no good at this.
{F3_MOTHER}: I can see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, {F3_DAUGHTER_7}. It‚Äôs not easy, let‚Äôs practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.
{F3_MOTHER}: Five catches in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, {F3_DAUGHTER_7}!
{F3_DAUGHTER_7}: Let‚Äôs do 10!
{F3_MOTHER}: I am very happy to be able to spend this special time with you, {F3_DAUGHTER_7}.

1Ô∏è‚É£ LEARN
2Ô∏è‚É£ NOTICE
3Ô∏è‚É£ OPEN
4Ô∏è‚É£ TALK
5Ô∏è‚É£ SHARE
6Ô∏è‚É£ CARE
Press Play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è to learn 6Ô∏è‚É£ six tips to learn how to notice feelings during one-on-one time
üí° Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions, all of which provide us with a very specific message:
üòÉHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.
üòîSad: Something important in your life needs attention.
üî¥Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.
üò£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.
üëÄSurprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.
üö©Afraid: Run away from danger.
üé® As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
This will make such a big difference. Great job! ‚≠ê
That‚Äôs okay. Try to make time this week.

üòí It is normal to have difficulty talking about and expressing emotions and feelings.
üìù Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

SourceText: Can you do it today?
Home Activity! During one-on-one time today, notice your child‚Äôs feelings. Talk to your child by describing both your own feelings and the feelings of your child.
This lesson is about how we can stay calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our children. üíö
As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness.
üå∑ We love our children, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life!
üí° It is important for us to try to stay calm in order to help manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
When I am angry at my child, I should show that I am angry so they stop misbehaving.
üíõ It can be very difficult when your child is misbehaving, but you should try to manage your own stress and check your anger before doing anything.
üå± Taking deep breaths will help. Being angry may cause you to say or do things you will later regret.
üéâ That‚Äôs correct!
{F2_GRANDFATHER} is about to spend one-on-one time with {F2_SON_8} but finds the living room is a mess. He notices that this makes her feel angry.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I‚Äôm feeling really angry. I am tired and my head feels hot. My mouth and throat are tight. I just want to shout at {F2_SON_8}.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I will Take a Pause and put on my favourite song.
{F2_GRANDFATHER} (thinking): I am feeling a little better. I can think more clearly about what to do to support my little boy.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: {F2_SON_8}, very good job doing your homework. You might be feeling tired now. Let's take a 5-minute break, and after that, we can play a game together to quickly pick up the toys.
{F2_GRANDFATHER}: Thank you for doing your part to keep the house clean, {F2_SON_8}! I‚Äôm so proud of your effort.  Oh! It is our one-on-one time. What would you like to do?
Here's a video that will help you stay calm when your child misbehaves. ‚òÄÔ∏è
1Ô∏è‚É£ BE CALM
2Ô∏è‚É£ BE QUICK
3Ô∏è‚É£ BE CLEAR
4Ô∏è‚É£ BE POSITIVE
Here's an audio message that will help you stay calm when your child misbehaves. ‚û°Ô∏è
There are four steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.
3Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CLEAR*
‚úÖ Rather than saying what you DON‚ÄôT want, tell your child what you DO want them to do.
For example, say:
‚ú® ‚ÄúPlease speak more softly.‚Äù
‚ú® ‚ÄúRemember to walk inside the house.‚Äù
This way, it is easier for them to follow! ‚≠ê
4Ô∏è‚É£ *BE POSITIVE*
‚úÖ Praise your child when they behave well!
‚úÖ Redirecting your child to a positive behaviour will help you manage the situation.
‚úÖ It will also help them know what you expect from them!

Home Activity! Remember to use these four steps if you start feeling stressed or angry during one-on-one time with your child. You can also share them with another member of your family. Sharing these tips will be great for everyone‚Äôs well-being. ‚û°Ô∏è
Can you share these tips today?
Amazing! ‚ú® Over the next few days, try to keep calm and redirect your child from a negative behaviour to a positive one before it gets worse.
That's OK! üìù Start by practising to Take a Pause even when you feel okay. This will help you be more ready when you feel stressed. ‚≠ê
Well done! üéâ You have learnt how to keep calm and redirect your child when you are feeling stressed!
You have completed @(fields.c_n_mod_compl +1) out of @fields.c_n_mod lessons in the course, Improve My Relationship with My Child üèÜ

SourceText: 1Ô∏è‚É£ *BE CALM*
‚úÖ Be aware of your own feelings.
‚úÖTake care of your emotions.
‚úÖRemember your goal: make @fields.child_nickname feel loved and secure.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: ‚úÖAct effectively: Take a pause or a few breaths before asking @fields.child_nickname to do something else.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: ‚úÖ Speak with @fields.child_nickname in a calm voice.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: ‚úÖRemember your goal: make your child feel loved and secure.
‚úÖAct effectively: Take a pause or a few breaths before asking your child to do something else.
‚úÖ Speak with your child in a calm voice.
2Ô∏è‚É£ *BE QUICK*
‚è∞ There are other things you can do to help manage unwanted behaviour before it becomes stressful.
‚ú®Praise something positive that your child did today.
‚ú®Understand their feelings. For example, it may feel boring to pick up toys after having fun or ending a big task.
‚ú®Ask your child to do something else, and distract them before the unwanted behaviour begins or gets worse.
‚ú®Invite @fields.child_nickname in a chore you are doing. You can ask @fields.child_nickname to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently.
note: Strings like @fields.xxx and @results.yyy should not be translated.

SourceText: üí° This is much easier than using consequences after they do something!
‚ú®Invite your child in a chore you are doing. You can ask your child to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently.
‚≠ê Before you focus on supporting others, it‚Äôs important to take care of yourself.
üò£ Feeling stressed as your children grow up is normal. As your relationship with them changes, it‚Äôs important to handle this shift well, and that starts with self-care.
üå± Self-care means doing things for yourself to reduce stress and make you feel better.
‚è∞ Let‚Äôs learn a simple way to handle everyday stress: Taking a pause.
‚ôª We will use this skill frequently in future lessons, so it is important to learn it today!
Taking a pause will help you manage stress and be more able to take care of others and yourself.üå±
Let's practise taking a pause together.
1Ô∏è‚É£ *SIT DOWN*
‚è∏  Find a place where you can sit comfortably.
‚≠ê You can close your eyes if you want.
2Ô∏è‚É£ *LISTEN*
üå± Take a deep breath.
üëÇ Feel the air moving in and out of your body.
üîÑ Repeat this 5 times.
3Ô∏è‚É£ *NOTICE*
‚ú® Notice how your body feels while you breathe.
üîµ Notice where you feel tension in your body and try to let it go.
4Ô∏è‚É£ *OPEN YOUR EYES*
üëÄ When you are ready, open your eyes.
üîë Notice if you feel any different than when you started this activity.
‚úÖ‚¨úÔ∏è
‚ñ∂Ô∏èPress Play to practise taking a pause together.
Try taking a pause whenever you feel angry, overwhelmed, stressed or worried. ‚è∞
Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also take a pause with your child or teen.
Try taking a pause on a daily basis, even if you are feeling calm. Doing this regularly will help your brain take a pause, even in challenging situations.
‚úÖ‚úÖ 100%
Well done! üéâ You have learnt the importance of caring for yourself and how to take a pause. ‚ú®
